Title: Absconding Zatwor
Genre: Action, Casual, Indie
Developer: Zonitron Productions
Publisher: GrabTheGames
Release Date6 Jul, 2015

Gameplay Now I got this one on sale, for like 15 cents, because why not. There's a tiny bit of stuffed in plot at the start, though you'll forget that about one minute into the game. This is a stealth game, where you calculate when is best to move, observe patterns in the cameras, noise detectors and guards, and hope you can make it to the next escape hole. It gets fraustrating super fast but you still want to complete it, and every time you're caught, the noise that plays when it happens will either give you a heart attack, a massive feeling of disappointment, or the urge to hit something, especially when you ALMOST made it to the end.

I think the music in the game changes too fast. It could stick with the same track for a few levels and then change. I don't think the music fits a stealth game, it changes too rapidly and doesn't suit the mood of the circumstances you're in.

It is meant to be a difficult/frustration game where you feel reward for getting past all those annoying obstacles, but I find myself getting annoyed too fast to really enjoy it. Maybe if  you have the patience for this, you'll enjoy it. In the beginning of the game as well you need to set your keybindings, but you can't move with the keys. You have to use your mouse to really progress.

Pros

I like the music tracks, however they don't fit with the game

Cons

Music doesn't fit the game
Controls are limited
Just no.

TL;DR

Overall VerdictI dislike this for reasons. Lots of reasons. I don't think it's worth the buy. Even with the sale. Just don't waste your time.

Overall - 1/5 - SAVE YOUR CHANGE!

The only thing AZ absconds with is your $1.09 - the story is relatively uninspired, the gameplay is elementary and grows stale fast, and the production value is the lowest I've seen in a Steam game in a long time. The idea is fertile - have players adventure through a complex, trap-laden prison; but with no change in the game beyond devices used in traps it squanders its potential as an adventure puzzler and quickly reveals itself for the shallow game it is. If you're looking to waste a dollar go ahead and try this out; otherwise, hold onto your money for now. And always be careful when heading out for smokes late at night.

reviewText:
Mouse-driven stealth game with an older-school design. Requires memorization of patterns and learning the level to complete it and requires precision and control of your character because if you're exposed by a couple of pixels you'll be hit and be forced to restart the whole level over again. There is no indicator to show if you're in cover so when the laser comes spinning around you have to pray that your backside isn't sticking out beyond the edge. Pretty mediocre story and graphics, mouse controls feel a lot better than keyboard controls.

Keyboard controls are 'tank controls' with a pretty wide turn radius so it's not so useful in a game that requires a lot of precision. I was hoping it'd be more useful in level 22 (which requires you to move in a perfect horizontal line) but your movement doesn't lock into a straight line (I usually moved in a straight line but often slightly upwards or downwards).
There might as well be a mode that allows both keyboard and mouse controls because they're both one-handed controls for different hands.

The game doesn't feel very polished; it's functional but without many settings and has several bugs/inconsistencies.

It saves your best time for a level but there are no leaderboards. It could be nice if it saved a ghost of your best time to race or had checkpoints so you could see split times for segments compared to your best time.

Cameras only see a certain range in front of them (it's pretty weird that a prison has nearsighted & narrowsighted cameras) and the vision indicators don't properly change to show how vision is limited by obstacles. However, lasers usually properly stop at obstacles so I'm guessing camera vision was harder to program. One exception is in level 30, where the lasers (but not bullets) pass through the exit doors. Machine guns are a little weird as well; they rotate faster the faster you run around them (instead of tracking at a steady pace).

I couldn't replicate the bug with the toggling" red lasers one review mentioned. However

reviewText:
Step into the most 'secure' prison in the world with most 'advance' security system all set up in rooms designed to allow a prisoner to slip by them!

Thrown there because you happened to be standing near a crime scene when the first police officer showed up and they decided to just throw you in jail...

Go up against the 'devious' security system of cameras that can't see more then a few feet in-front of themselves and that move reaaaaalllly slowly!

Try and fail numerous time to slip by the 'state of the art' noise detectors that apparently operate on some sort of sonar motion detector instead of actually detecting noise... okay.

James Bond your way though laser 'super advance' trip wires that don't actually function like laser trip wires since a box can cross their path and it wont set them off like a real trip wire system should...  okay... really?

Fear the machine gun turrets that track targets really slowly and shoot slow moving bullets...

Okay I think Zatwor Prison really REALLY needs to get a refund on this security system of theirs.  Who designed this! ACME?!  Seriously.   A balding middle age man just broke out like the place was made of wet cardboard!

=========================================================

The game plays basically like a flash game that you can play for free online except now you can pay for it!  (yay?)

You're a guy, you can move, keep out of the sight of the cameras and dodge lasers or you get sent back to the beginning of the level.

Some of the levels become obnoxiously frustrating and I'm pretty sure the only reasons I won those ones was because I glitched the game somehow.

The controls are practically nonexistent.

Really I can't fault them for making the game. Making games is how you get better at making games...  But they shouldn't have sold it for money...  The fact that I payed for it makes me wish that I got a refund before the deadline to get one was up... so now I'm stuck with it.
